questions.text: You are working as the PHC Medical Officer in your village. Which of the following diseases would you not target under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) does not target the prevention and control of cutaneous leishmaniasis (also known as Chiclero's ulcer).

NVBDCP is the nodal agency for the prevention and control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Lymphatic filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis 
  • Chikungunya.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia

  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text:
Which of the following is carried out by the Drug Distribution Centres under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme for Malaria?
  1. Collection of the blood slides
  2. Distribution of antimalarial tablets
  3. Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) spraying operations
  4. Case-based surveillance
questions.solution:
The Drug Distribution Centres are only for dispensing anti-malarial drugs, under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) for Malaria. 

The organizational structure for the Anti-Malaria Programme is as follows:

  • Central Government: supplies DDT and larvicides.
  • State government: procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts.
  • District Malaria Office: is the key unit for the implementation of the programme.
  • District Malaria Officer: has the direct responsibility of IRS spraying operations and is assisted by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. 
  • Medical officer of the PHC: has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory services.
  • Multi-Purpose Workers and ASHAs: carry out case-based surveillance and case detection in the community.
  • Drug Distribution Centres: only for dispensing the antimalarial drugs.
  • Fever Treatment Depots: collect blood slides in addition to the distribution of antimalarial drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the surveillance system set up for malaria?

choices.text: Active case detection is carried out when patients report with fever to the peripheral health workers
Blood smears are collected fortnightly during house visits by Accredited Social Health Activists
Antibody detecting rapid diagnostic kits are used for passive case detection as part of surveillance
Passive case detection at the Primary Health Centre is done by examination of blood smears

questions.solution:
Passive case detection at Primary Health Centres (PHCs) is done by examination of blood smears.

Malaria surveillance system:

Active case detection: blood smears are collected by the Multipurpose Health Workers (MPHW)/ Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) on house visits every fortnight.

Passive case detection: detection of fever case by collecting of blood smears of those that report to ASHAs or peripheral health volunteers.

questions.text: Which of the following measures for controlling malaria is the Urban Malaria Scheme mainly based on?
questions.solution:
The Urban Malaria Scheme is mainly based on anti-larval measures for controlling malaria. In Urban Malaria Scheme, urban areas with a population of >50,000 and a slide positivity rate of ≥5% are included. 

The vector in urban areas breeds in man-made containers. Therefore, anti-larval measures such as larvivorous fish and larvicides are used to control breeding as the primary method of vector control.

In rural areas, anti-adult measures, such as Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) is the primary method of vector control.

questions.text: What is the most efficient anti-larval method to prevent urban malaria?
questions.solution: The most efficient anti-larval method to prevent urban malaria is to cover overhead tanks and other man-made containers properly. This is because the vector of malaria in urban areas breeds largely in such man-made containers.

questions.text: The blood smear slides (A) and (B) prepared from a patient suspected with malaria are shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding these tests?

choices.text: Slide (A) is used for estimating the parasite concentration
Slide (A) has been air dried for 10 minutes
Slide (B) cannot be used for detecting the species of the parasite
Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for both

questions.solution:
Slide (A) is a thin blood smear and slide (B) is a thick blood smear. Thin blood smears (slide A) are not used for estimating parasite concentration. They are used to detect the species of parasite.

Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due to its high sensitivity and specificity. Jaswant Singh Battacharya (JSB) stain is used for staining both thick and thin smears.

Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration. The correct thickness is the thickness through which a newsprint is barely visible. It is prepared by slow-drying for 30 minutes, which leads to hemolysis and distortion of the plasmodia morphology. Hence, species cannot be detected.

Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium. It is prepared by air drying for 10 minutes and fixed in methanol. Thus, the plasmodia morphology is not distorted.

questions.text: The following two diagnostic techniques (A) and (B) were performed in a medical camp conducted for diagnosing malaria. Which is a true statement regarding these techniques?

choices.text: Image (A) - It is used for identifying the species of the malarial parasite
Image (A) - It is not the established method of choice for diagnosing malaria in urban areas
Image (B) - Antibody detection by this test is the method of choice for diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas
Image (B) - Bivalent type of this test was used for detecting Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax

questions.solution:
Image (A) is a thick blood smear and Image (B) is the Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT). Bivalent RDTs detect P. falciparum and P. vivax.

Thin blood smear is used to identify the particular infecting species. Thick blood smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.

Antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) are not the method of choice anymore in diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas. The Antigen detecting RDTs and blood smear examination are the recommended methods for diagnosis of malaria.

Note: According to the announcement by Union Health Ministry in April 2018, antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) for malaria is banned due to the high false-positive rates in endemic areas.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters would you use to check the efficiency of the surveillance system for malaria under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
The Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER) is used to check the efficiency of the surveillance system for malaria. It takes into account the number of slides examined for the population under surveillance.

World Malaria Day is conducted on April 25 every year.

questions.text: According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India, states are classified based on which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence (API) is used in classifying states/UTs according to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. 

The Annual Parasite Incidence is calculated as: (Cases in one year ×1000) / (Population under surveillance).

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the classification of malaria endemic states under the National Strategic Plan for Malaria?

choices.text: The states classified under Category 0  are in the elimination phase
The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase
The states with districts reporting API in between 1-2 per 1000 population are in the elimination phase
The states classified under category 2 are in the phase of intensified control

questions.solution:
The National Strategic Plan for Malaria classifies the states under Category 1 of the NVBDCP to be in the elimination phase. 

Category 1 states are all states/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1.

questions.text: A rural medical officer implements Integrated Vector Management in his village. Which of the following measures of vector control would you prefer in a rural area?
questions.solution:
The measure of vector control preferred for rural areas is indoor residual spray (IRS).

Under integrated vector management (IVM), the preferred measures of vector control for

  • Rural areas include: Anti-adult measures, using indoor residual spray (IRS)
  • Urban areas include: Anti-larval measures, like environmental control by source reduction, chemical control (mineral oils, Paris green, synthetic insecticides, etc.), and biological control (fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebistes reticulatus which feed on mosquito larvae).

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: Select the correct option regarding Intergrated Vector Management:

choices.text: Malathion is the insecticide of choice used for vector management
Larvivorous fish and larvicides are the main methods of vector control in rural areas
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets are provided in areas with API ≥5
Insecticide treated bed nets are supplied in areas with API ≥3

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated Vector Management initiative, Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥5.

Integrated Vector Management (IVM):

  • For adult mosquitoes:
    • Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are used as the main method of vector control in rural areas. The insecticide of choice will be the insecticide to which the local vector is susceptible as per the best available information. 
    • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT, and in DDT resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with malathion.
  • For larvae: 
    • Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.
  • For personal protection: 
    • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥2.
    • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥5.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in Jharkhand, which is endemic to the disease transmitted by the vector shown below. Which of the following agents would you prefer to control this vector in view of resistance to commonly used agents?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly, which is the vector for kala-azar. In endemic states with increasing resistance to commonly used agents like DDT, synthetic pyrethroids are preferred now.

The four states endemic for kala-azar are Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal and Uttar Pradesh.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: According to the revised strategy for the eradication of kala-azar, which of the following drugs would you use across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection?
questions.solution:
A single dose of intravenous treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is used across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection. WHO will supply this drug free of cost. 

Drugs for Kala Azar:

  • Single-dose intravenous liposomal amphotericin B for all age groups and for pregnant and HIV co-infected patients.
  • Miltefosine- an oral drug, once daily for 28 days. Contraindicated during pregnancy, lactation, and in women who refuse contraception.
  • Combination of miltefosine capsules with paromomycin i.m, for 10 days. Contraindications are the same as miltefosine.
  • The drug of choice for Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is miltefosine 100mg orally per day for 12 weeks.

Ivermectin is used for lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the elimination and eradication of lymphatic filariasis is true?

choices.text: It will be considered as eliminated when the number of microfilaria carriers are less than 5 percent
It will be considered as eliminated when children born after initiation of the programme are free from antigenemia
India has set the target of eliminating lymphatic filariasis by 2025
WHO recommends dual therapy with diethylcarbamazine and albendazole for elimination of transmission

questions.solution:
Lymphatic filariasis will be considered eliminated when the children born after the initiation of the programme are free from antigenemia. Antigenemia refers to the presence of adult filaria worms in the human body.

According to the Elimination of Lymphatic Filariasis (ELF) Programme, there are two criteria to consider elimination of lymphatic filariasis:

  • Children born after the initiation of the elimination programme are free from circulating antigenemia.
  • The number of microfilaria carriers is <1%.

Following the failure to achieve ELF by 2015, the target set to eliminate lymphatic filariasis by WHO was 2020. To achieve the same WHO recommended the use of triple therapy for lymphatic filariasis. It incorporated ivermectin along with diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and albendazole instead of the traditional DEC and albendazole therapy, for the elimination of transmission of lymphatic filariasis.

In 2021, WHO released the 'Road Map for Neglected Tropical Diseases (2021–2030)'. Under this, lymphatic filariasis is targeted for elimination as a public health problem by 2030.

In February 2023, the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare in India launched a nationwide Sarva Dawa Sevan or Mass Drug Administration (MDA) campaign to eliminate LF by 2027, aiming to achieve this goal three years ahead of the global target.

questions.text: As the medical officer in a Japanese encephalitis endemic area, which of the following measures would you not advocate for controlling its transmission?

choices.text: The use of Indoor Residual Sprays
Keeping pigs away from human dwellings
The use of malathion for outdoor fogging

questions.solution:
Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) are not used in the vector control measures for Japanese Encephalitis (JE) as its vectors (Culex) are outdoor resters. 

Prevention and control of JE include:

  • Vaccination
  • Keeping pigs away from human dwellings from dusk to dawn (biting time of the vectors). Pigs act as important amplifiers of the virus.
  • Use of bed nets for personal protection.
  • Use of larvivorous fishes.
  • Using malathion for outdoor fogging to control an outbreak.
